h1.span: April 9, 2020 COVID-19 Update from the RI Department of Health

td.style: background: rgb(255, 255, 255) none no-repeat scroll center center / cover; border-top: 0px none; border-bottom: 0px none; padding-top: 9px; padding-bottom: 0px; width: 1130px;
background: rgb(255, 255, 255) none no-repeat scroll center center / cover; border-top: 0px none; border-bottom: 2px solid rgb(234, 234, 234); padding-top: 0px; padding-bottom: 9px; width: 1130px;
padding: 0px 18px 9px; word-break: break-word; color: rgb(32, 32, 32); font-family: Helvetica; font-size: 16px; line-height: 150%; text-align: left; width: 951px;

br.span:
The Rhode Island Department of Health (RIDOH), our partners across the State, and national public health officials continue to respond to coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). As the situation evolves, we want to make sure that our communities and our healthcare system are prepared. Being informed is an important part of being prepared. For that reason, we intend to send regular Partner Briefings, such as this, to our community partners with updates and key information. Please share this briefing with your colleagues and networks.
Rhode Island COVID-19 Updates
As of April 9, Rhode Island has 1,727 cases (including presumptive positive cases. This is preliminary data). Two hundred and seventy-seven new cases were announced on April 9. Rhode Island has had 43 deaths associated with COVID-19. For Rhode Island COVID-19 data, please visit the RIDOH COVID-19 website.
Recent news and guidance
Testing

li.span: Please visit https://health.ri.gov/covid/testing/ to find out how you can get tested for COVID-19 in Rhode Island.
There have been significant changes to how Rhode Island is testing for COVID-19 over the past week.

Previously, we focused our testing efforts on certain high-priority groups. Now that the State has expanded its testing capacity, anyone who is experiencing any of the following symptoms should call their healthcare provider or an urgent care center to request a test: fever, cough, shortness of breath, muscle aches (myalgias), chills, runny nose or stuffy nose, sore throat, headache, or diarrhea.
In addition, Rhode Island has partnered with CVS Health to make free, rapid COVID-19 tests available to Rhode Islanders, doubling the state's testing capacity.
These rapid tests are provided by appointment at a new drive-through testing site at Twin River Casino in Lincoln. This testing site will be able to perform approximately 1,000 tests per day.
Through CVS, people will be able to get their test results within 30 minutes.
The CVS rapid test is only available to Rhode Island residents over the age of 18.
Please do not go to a CVS pharmacy for this test. Please go to the CVS website to schedule your test.
Do I need an appointment for a test?
Yes. No matter what site you go to, you will need an appointment to be tested. You can get an appointment through a healthcare provider or through the CVS website.
I would like my child to get tested. What do I do?
Please call your pediatrician and discuss your child’s symptoms. Your pediatrician can order and schedule a test.

Parents and caregivers can swab their own children at drive-up testing sites operated by the National Guard (Community College of Rhode Island (CCRI) in Warwick, University of Rhode Island (URI) in South Kingstown, and Rhode Island College (RIC) in Providence), with coaching from staff at the site. If parents are uncomfortable with obtaining a sample from their child, they can call a respiratory clinic. A list of respiratory clinics that accept pediatric patients is available here.
I don’t have health insurance but would like to be tested. What do I do?
You will be charged for a COVID-19 test and/or a doctor’s visit if you go to a Respiratory Clinic or to a healthcare provider’s office.
You can get a free COVID-19 test two ways:
Call your healthcare provider (if you have one) to get an order for a COVID-19 test at one of the drive-up testing sites at URI, CCRI, or RIC.
Go to the CVS website to be pre-screened for testing and to get an appointment.
I don’t have a primary care provider but would like to be tested. What do I do?
Please call an urgent care or a respiratory clinic to explain your symptoms and to request a test. Please be sure to call the facility before showing up.
A list of urgent care centers, health centers, and other non-emergent treatment options is available at health.ri.gov/urgentcare. People should call healthcare facilities before going to them.
I can’t wait multiple days for a test result. Is there a better option?

Yes. CVS offers rapid tests by appointment at a new drive-through testing site at Twin River Casino in Lincoln. Please note you must be a Rhode Island resident and older than 18 years old to have this test.

* Rapid tests are intended for essential workers (or people who still have to go to their place of employment), healthcare workers, older adults, and others who may benefit from knowing their test results immediately. If you can afford to wait for a few days, please seek testing at URI, CCRI, RIC, or a respiratory clinic offering testing.

We are aware that there is a national shortage of personal protective equipment (PPE), and that it may be difficult to find hand sanitizer at this time. There are other things you can use in your home to protect you and your household members.
Remember to wash your hands frequently with soap and water.

The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has put together a list of easy steps to clean and disinfect your household, without relying on hand sanitizer: Cleaning and disinfecting your home (CDC)
For a more comprehensive guide for household cleaning and disinfection, please visit: Cleaning and disinfection for households (CDC)

Most household cleaners are effective against the virus that causes COVID-19. For a comprehensive list of cleaners that kill this virus, please visit: Disinfectants for Use Against SARS-CoV-2 (Environmental Protection Agency).
The Governor signed an executive order today that clarifies Rhode Island’s requirements around quarantine and isolation. The related press release can be found here.

Anyone diagnosed with COVID-19—either by a laboratory test or through symptom assessment by a healthcare provider—must self-isolate. People in isolation must stay at home and stay in isolation for at least seven days. Additionally, someone needs to be fever free for 72 hours without the use of fever reducing medication, and all their symptoms need to have resolved completely before they can come out of isolation.
People in quarantine must distance themselves from others, including at home. These people should monitor themselves for symptoms.
Anyone who has been in close contact with an individual who has been diagnosed with COVID-19 must quarantine for 14 days, regardless of whether they present symptoms or not.
For more information about quarantine and isolation, please visit the RIDOH website.
This week, Governor Gina M. Raimondo announced the following Executive Orders would be extended until May 8:
All social gatherings of more than five people are prohibited (this includes religious services).
Restaurants, bars, and cafes are closed to dine-in service.
Public recreation, entertainment, non-essential retail, and close-contact businesses are closed to in-person operations.
Anyone arriving in Rhode Island from out of state or internationally, by any mode of transportation, must self-quarantine for 14 days.
The provision of the Open Meetings Act that prohibits meetings taking place by phone or video conferencing is suspended.
Health insurers must cover telemedicine for primary care, specialty care, and mental and behavioral healthcare.
Gun permit background checks have been extended from 7 days to 30 days, in alignment with police recommendations.
In addition, the following closures will extend indefinitely:
The State House is closed to visitors.
Nursing homes, hospitals and the Adult Correctional Institutions (ACI) are not allowing visitors until further notice.
State parks and beaches are closed.
All state-based customer services – for example, services from the Department of Human Services (DHS), Department of Labor and Training (DLT), and HealthSource RI (HSRI) – will remain online only.
The Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) is open by appointment only. All road tests are suspended indefinitely.
Casinos are closed indefinitely.

If you are concerned that you may be sick with COVID-19 or you develop severe symptoms, call your healthcare provider or an urgent care center before showing up at a facility. This will give the facility time to prepare to meet your needs while protecting healthcare workers.
If you have symptoms of COVID-19, and you are self-isolating, the people that you were in contact with while you were sick should also quarantine themselves and monitor for symptoms.
Use a cloth face covering to help slow the spread of COVID-19 (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)
Protect yourself:
Please keep in mind that most people who are mildly ill may be able to isolate and care for themselves at home.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after going to the bathroom; before eating; and after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing.
If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Always wash hands with soap and water if hands are visibly dirty.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth.
Stay home when you are sick.
Cover your cough or sneeze with your sleeve or a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Clean (remove dirt, dust, soil, organic matter) and disinfect (using a chemical product to kill pathogens) frequently touched objects and surfaces using a regular household cleaning spray or wipe.
RIDOH has activated an information line for COVID-19. For general COVID-19 questions, please call 401-222-8022 or email RIDOH.COVID19Questions@health.ri.gov.
For COVID-19 information and employment questions, please call the Department of Labor and Training at 401-462-2020, or email dlt.covid19@dlt.ri.gov.
People experiencing a behavioral health crisis can call BH Link at 401-414-5465.

Parents seeking information about urgent behavioral health issues their kids are experiencing should call Kids’ Link—a separate service administered by Bradley Hospital/Lifespan: 1-855-543-5465. This is available 24/7.
If you are looking for employment in Rhode Island, please visit EmployRI.

If you are looking for a way to help your neighbors, or if you need help, go to www.NextDoor.com. NextDoor is a social media platform for neighborhoods. You can use their Help Map feature to see who in your neighborhood needs help, and you can connect to provide that help.
If you or someone you know is experiencing domestic violence, please reach out to Rhode Island Coalition Against Domestic Violence: 1-800-494-8100.
If you are in quarantine or isolation and in need of food, grocery delivery, or support from mutual aid groups, please visit RIDelivers: http://ridelivers.com
For COVID-19 information and resources in American Sign Language, please visit the Rhode Island Commission on the Deaf and Hard of Hearing’s COVID-19 page: http://www.cdhh.ri.gov/covid-19/
Occupational Safety and Health Administration: Guidance for Retail Workers: (English) (Spanish)
How to report the unlawful sale of medical products on the Internet (US Food and Drug Administration)
Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) updates:
Counterfeit Respirators/Misrepresentation of NIOSH Approval (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)
Emergency Use Authorizations of PPE (US Food and Drug Administration)
Strategies to Optimize the Supply of PPE and Equipment (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)
Previous COVID-19 Updates:

p.span: Please contact RIDOH Infectious Disease Communications Coordinator Aaron Frechette (aaron.frechette@health.ri.gov) for assistance with educational materials and communication resources. To be added to this distribution list to receive future communications, email Anna Tomasulo (anna.tomasulo@health.ri.gov). Please contact the RIDOH COVID-19 Information Line at 401-222-8022, or email RIDOH.covid19questions@health.ri.gov, with any other questions.
